clean_story:
"Matter’s building blocks. Fermions obey strict rules. "

"Fermion" comes from Enrico Fermi, the physicist who studied their behavior—particles that refuse to overlap, like stubborn dancers keeping personal space.


Electrons, protons, neutrons. These are fermions—the particles that form atoms, and thus everything you touch. Unlike light particles (photons), fermions cannot occupy the same state at once. Picture a crowded elevator: no two people can stand in the exact same spot. This rule, the Pauli Exclusion Principle, keeps matter stable.

Without it, atoms would collapse. Electrons in an atom stack into layers, like seats in a stadium—each level holds only so many. This structure defines chemistry: why gold glitters, why oxygen binds to blood.

Neutron stars push fermions to extremes. Under crushing gravity, their "no-overlap" rule resists total collapse, creating the densest observable matter—a sugar-cube-sized piece weighs as much as a mountain.

Three related subjects are quantum spin mechanics, white dwarf stability, and how superconductors defy fermion rules.
